title: Airbus A320 Aircraft Maintenance Manual
content: This Aircraft Maintenance Manual (AMM) provides detailed procedures for maintaining the Airbus A320 aircraft. It contains essential information for maintenance personnel to ensure the aircraft remains in an airworthy condition. The manual is organized by ATA chapters and includes detailed illustrations, diagrams, and step-by-step procedures.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: This Aircraft Maintenance Manual (AMM) contains information necessary for the maintenance of the Airbus A320 aircraft. It is organized according to the Air Transport Association (ATA) specification 100 chapter system. This manual is intended for use by properly trained and qualified maintenance personnel. All maintenance procedures must be performed in accordance with this manual and applicable regulatory requirements. The manual is regularly updated to incorporate the latest service information. Always ensure you are using the most current revision.

sections.title: Safety Precautions
sections.content:
WARNING: Before performing any maintenance procedure, ensure that all necessary safety precautions are taken. Failure to observe safety precautions may result in personal injury, damage to equipment, or both.

CAUTION: Always follow proper lockout/tagout procedures when working on electrical or hydraulic systems.

The following general safety precautions must be observed:
1. Always wear appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE)
2. Ensure the aircraft is properly grounded before maintenance
3. Disable all electrical power before working on electrical systems
4. Relieve all hydraulic pressure before working on hydraulic systems
5. Use proper lifting techniques and equipment when handling heavy components
6. Follow all warnings and cautions in the specific maintenance procedures

sections.title: Electrical System Description
sections.content:
The Airbus A320 electrical system consists of the following main components:

1. AC Power Generation System
   - Two engine-driven generators (115V AC, 400Hz, 90 kVA each)
   - One Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) generator (115V AC, 400Hz, 90 kVA)
   - One external power connection (115V AC, 400Hz, 90 kVA)

2. AC Power Distribution System
   - AC Bus 1 and AC Bus 2 (primary distribution buses)
   - AC Essential Bus (supplies essential equipment)
   - AC Emergency Bus (supplies emergency equipment)

3. DC Power Generation System
   - Three Transformer Rectifier Units (TRUs) converting 115V AC to 28V DC
   - Battery 1 and Battery 2 (24V DC, 23 Ah each)

4. DC Power Distribution System
   - DC Bus 1 and DC Bus 2 (primary DC distribution buses)
   - DC Essential Bus (supplies essential DC equipment)
   - DC Emergency Bus (supplies emergency DC equipment)
   - Hot Battery Bus (directly connected to Battery 1)

5. Static Inverter
   - Converts 28V DC to 115V AC, 400Hz for the AC Emergency Bus when normal AC power is not available

The electrical system is designed with multiple redundancies to ensure continued operation in case of component failures. The system is controlled and monitored by two Electrical Power Control Units (EPCUs) that automatically manage power generation, distribution, and load shedding.

Cross-reference: For detailed component information, refer to the Illustrated Parts Catalog.

sections.title: Electrical System Maintenance Procedures
sections.content:
4.1 BATTERY REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION

WARNING: Batteries contain corrosive electrolyte and can produce explosive gases. Wear appropriate PPE including eye protection and acid-resistant gloves.

Tools Required:
- Standard mechanic's tool set
- Digital multimeter
- Torque wrench (0-20 Nm)

Removal Procedure:
1. Ensure all aircraft electrical power is OFF
2. Access the battery compartment in the avionics bay
3. Disconnect the battery temperature sensor connector
4. Disconnect the negative (-) battery terminal first, then the positive (+) terminal
5. Remove the battery hold-down clamps
6. Remove the battery from the aircraft using the built-in carrying handle

Installation Procedure:
1. Inspect the battery compartment for cleanliness and damage
2. Place the battery in the battery compartment
3. Install and secure the battery hold-down clamps
4. Connect the positive (+) battery terminal first, then the negative (-) terminal
5. Torque the battery terminal nuts to 10-12 Nm
6. Connect the battery temperature sensor connector
7. Perform the battery capacity check as described in Section 4.2

4.2 BATTERY CAPACITY CHECK

Tools Required:
- Battery capacity tester (P/N: BATT-TEST-001)
- Digital multimeter

Procedure:
1. Ensure the battery is fully charged (minimum 24V under no load)
2. Connect the battery capacity tester to the battery
3. Set the tester for a 1-hour discharge test at the 1C rate (23A)
4. Start the test and monitor the battery voltage
5. Record the battery voltage every 10 minutes
6. The test is complete when either:
   a. The 1-hour test period has elapsed, or
   b. The battery voltage drops below 20V

Acceptance Criteria:
- The battery must maintain a voltage above 20V for at least 45 minutes
- The final capacity must be at least 80% of the rated capacity (18.4 Ah)

If the battery fails the capacity check, it must be replaced.

4.3 GENERATOR BRUSH INSPECTION

CAUTION: Ensure the engine or APU is shut down and cannot be started during this procedure.

Tools Required:
- Inspection mirror
- Flashlight
- Brush wear gauge (P/N: GEN-GAUGE-001)
- Vacuum cleaner with non-metallic nozzle

Procedure:
1. Access the generator through the appropriate access panel
2. Remove the brush inspection cover
3. Use the flashlight and mirror to inspect the brushes for wear, chipping, or abnormal wear patterns
4. Use the brush wear gauge to measure the length of each brush
5. Vacuum any carbon dust from the brush area
6. Inspect the slip rings for scoring, pitting, or discoloration
7. Reinstall the brush inspection cover

Acceptance Criteria:
- Minimum brush length: 12 mm
- No chipping or abnormal wear patterns
- Slip rings must be clean and free of significant scoring or pitting

If any brush is worn beyond limits or damaged, replace the brush set according to the procedure in the Component Maintenance Manual.

sections.title: Electrical System Troubleshooting
sections.content:
5.1 TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE

This section provides guidance for identifying and resolving common electrical system issues.

Symptom: Generator Fails to Come Online
Possible Causes:
1. Generator Control Unit (GCU) fault
   - Check GCU fault codes using the maintenance computer
   - Replace GCU if faulty
2. Generator drive mechanism failure
   - Inspect the generator drive for proper operation
   - Check for sheared drive shaft or coupling
3. Generator internal fault
   - Perform generator insulation test
   - Check for brush wear or slip ring damage
4. Open circuit in generator feeder
   - Check continuity of generator feeder cables
   - Inspect connectors for damage or contamination

Symptom: Battery Discharges Rapidly
Possible Causes:
1. Battery cell failure
   - Perform battery capacity test
   - Check individual cell voltages
2. Charging system fault
   - Check TRU output voltage (should be 28V Â± 0.5V)
   - Inspect charging circuit wiring
3. Excessive current draw
   - Check for abnormal current draw with all systems off
   - Look for short circuits or ground faults
4. Battery age
   - Check battery service date
   - Replace if beyond service life

Symptom: Intermittent Power to Equipment
Possible Causes:
1. Loose connections
   - Inspect and tighten all relevant electrical connections
   - Check for corrosion or contamination
2. Circuit breaker issues
   - Check for thermal cycling of circuit breakers
   - Replace suspect circuit breakers
3. Relay or contactor problems
   - Check relay or contactor operation
   - Listen for chattering or buzzing
4. Wiring insulation breakdown
   - Perform insulation resistance tests
   - Look for signs of wire chafing or damage

CAUTION: Always refer to the appropriate Service Bulletin for the latest troubleshooting information and updates to maintenance procedures.

sections.title: Inspection Requirements
sections.content:
6.1 SCHEDULED INSPECTIONS

The following inspections must be performed at the specified intervals:

Daily Inspection:
- Visual check of external power receptacle
- Check battery charge status via cockpit indicator
- Verify all essential lights are operational

7-Day Inspection:
- Check emergency light system operation
- Inspect visible electrical wiring for damage
- Test ground power control system

600-Hour Inspection:
- Perform detailed inspection of all accessible electrical equipment
- Check generator brushes for wear
- Inspect electrical connectors for corrosion or damage
- Test battery capacity

1200-Hour Inspection:
- Perform insulation resistance tests on main generators
- Check TRU performance under load
- Inspect electrical busses for overheating or damage
- Test all electrical system protection devices

6000-Hour Inspection:
- Remove and overhaul main generators
- Perform detailed wiring inspection throughout aircraft
- Check bonding resistance of all major electrical components
- Replace batteries regardless of condition

NOTE: Additional inspections may be required by Airworthiness Directives or Service Bulletins.

sections.title: Wiring Diagrams
sections.content:
7.1 ELECTRICAL SYSTEM WIRING DIAGRAMS

This section contains wiring diagrams for the major electrical systems. Each diagram shows the interconnections between components, wire identification numbers, connector pin assignments, and circuit protection devices.

The following wiring diagrams are included:

- Figure 24-1: AC Power Generation and Distribution
- Figure 24-2: DC Power Generation and Distribution
- Figure 24-3: Battery System
- Figure 24-4: External Power System
- Figure 24-5: Emergency Power System
- Figure 24-6: Generator Control System
- Figure 24-7: Bus Power Control System
- Figure 24-8: Load Shedding System

Wire Identification System:

Wires are identified using the following format:

ABCDEFG

Where:
A = System (e.g., 2 for Electrical Power)
B = Subsystem (e.g., 4 for DC Generation)
C = Unit (e.g., 1 for Battery 1)
D = Function (e.g., C for Control)
EFG = Sequential number

Example: 241CB01 identifies a wire in the Electrical Power (2) DC Generation (4) Battery 1 (1) Control (C) circuit, wire number 01.

Connector Identification System:

Connectors are identified using the following format:

ABCD-EF

Where:
ABCD = Equipment identification
EF = Connector position on the equipment

Example: 2435-12 identifies connector position 12 on equipment 2435 (Battery 1 Control Unit).
